div.head: Capitulum 5
Why the sacraments have been instituted
div.p: The sacraments have been instituted from three reasons: in order to humble, for instruction, and for training.

In order to humble, such that while man, standing in reverence according to the command of the creator, subjects himself, to sensible things, which are below him in nature, from this humility and obedience he pleases God more greatly and earns merit from him, by whose command he seeks salvation amoung things inferior to himself, even though this salvation does not come from these things but from God through them.

It has also been instituted on account of instruction, such that through the fact that is considered externally in a visible species, the mind would be instructed to discern the invisible power that is internal. For man, who before sin saw God without an intermediary, through sin has become dim such that he cannot grasp the divine, unless he is trained with human things.

The are similarly instituted on account of training: because, when is not able to be leisurely, useful and healthy training in the sacraments is proposed, through which he holds off empty and harmful occupations. For he is not easily captured by temptations who has prepared himself with good training; whence
Jerome
advises:
Always do something good, so that the devil finds you occupied.
Hieronymus, Epis 125, Ad Rustic. n. 11 (PL 22, 1078) . But instruction is of three types: one that pertains to the edification of the soul, another of alleviation of the soul, and another for the subversion of both.
Therefore since without the sacraments, such that God did not bind his own power to these things, he would still be able to give grace to man, he instituted the Sacraments for the aforesaid reasons.
But there are two things, in which the Sacrament consists, namely the word and the thing: the word, such as the invocation of the Trinity; the thing, such as the water, oil, or things of this type.
